campaign.story:
MOVING ON EDIT-A-THON
What is an Edit-a-thon? Think back to the days of all nighters during finals week, add the passion of global hope and hearts changed, all the while waking up to the snowy peaks of the Rocky Mountains. For 21 days, 4 documentary gurus at the top of their game in the film industry will be sitting in a room staring at computer screens with empty energy drinks all over the floor. Their hair un-kept and flying all over the place, looking like Albert Einstein, with big grins on their faces because they know that what they are making is going to inspire and instill hope on those who see what they have created.
What is being edited? MOVING ON (www.MovingOnMovie.com) is a feature-length film we have been working on for the past year to show the world that Africa is changing us and everyone who bids to enter in. We are inches away from finishing the feature length Rough Cut. You are invited to help us complete this project so we can help spread hope to the world.
What is this all about? Hope is winning for the people of Africa and we want you to experience it too! Who knew this would all start by the adoption of our daughter? Who knew that the people we work with in Uganda through our non-profit Light Gives Heat (www.lightgivesheat.org) would change us and mold us into the people that we are today? Everyone that has come on board with us as staff or volunteers has been changed and inspired by the hope we see in Africa. MOVING ON recently won Grand Prize in Panasonic's 'Shoot It, Share It' contest - it's a huge honor, check it out. ~FAQs~ Is MOVING ON a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization? YES. The film is a project of Light Gives Heat, a certified 501(c)3 non-profit organization. ALL PLEDGES ARE TAX-DEDUCTIBLE and LGH will provide a receipt for the 2011 tax year!
Where does this money go and where can it take us? All of the money (aside from Kickstarter fees/incentives) will go directly towards our 21-day MOVING ON Edit-a-thon and ensure that a rough-cut of the film will be completed by March 23rd, 2011. After the rough-edit is done, we still will have more editing, animation, music licensing/creation, and other post-production magic, but this $10,000 is part of the $25,000 Light Gives Heat is trying to raise to see a rough cut finished by the end of March 2011.
$10,000 seems like a low amount to get a rough cut of a film done... Yes, $10,000 is our Kickstarter goal, but our real needs for our MOVING ON Edit-a-thon in March 2011 are $25,000 and we will be doing other fundraising locally to help meet the additional funding goal. Up until this point, the project has been funded by gracious donors, the winnings of $20,000 through a Chase Community Giving Grant, and our initial start-up loan. The $10,000 figure is the amount we felt comfortable aiming for in Kickstarter because as you know, unless we meet our goal we don't get any of the pledges. In actuality, the $10,000 is part of a larger remaining balance of $150,000 that will allow us to fully fund the film, see it through completion, and enter it into film festivals (as well as pay back our original start-up loan). If we could generate more than $10,000 in this campaign, we would be stoked! Don't forget, with MOVING ON, we do have benefit of offering a tax-deductible receipt ;)
How and when will you get contact information to fulfill the incentives? If and when we successfully reach our deadline we get your email address. At this point, we will contact you for any relevant information. You’ll tell us what size t-shirt to send you, who you want the SUUBI necklace mailed to, and of course- who's coming to our Rough Cut Reveal night on March 23rd, 2011! We’ll send out those emails pronto, so just make sure you get back to us- the sooner we get the contact info, the sooner your prizes can ship.
Can I increase my pledge once it’s been made? YES! Once you donate to MOVING ON, you may want to change your incentive reward by increasing your pledge amount. To do so, go to Kickstarter and sign in. If you go to our campaign page, the green “Back This Project” button will have been replaced with a blue “Manage Your Donation” button. Click it and you can enter a new amount, or choose a new incentive.
What happens if the money isn’t raised in time? This is what we’re working to avoid. If we don’t reach our goal then no exchange is made. You don’t pay and we have to find another way to fund this film- bad news all around.
Can we exceed the goal? YES! And honestly, we need that to happen. Again, we are just trying to get creative and the $10,000 figure is part of a $25,000 goal we have for the month of March 2011 and our MOVING ON Edit-a-thon. So, the pledges can keep on rolling in, even after our goal is met, until our deadline- February 28th.
When will the film release? We get asked all the time, and trust us when we say that we want to know a release date more than anybody! The reality is that this production has turned into something bigger and more beautiful than we anticipated - which is a good thing. Our goal is a finalized film in summer 2011 and to do the Film Festival circuit with hopes of releasing to the public in Spring/Summer 2012. This is long-term thinking, we know, but since this a collaboration, YOU can help play an essential role and the truth is WE NEED YOU!
Any other questions? Contact us at MovingOn@lightgivesheat.org
~The MOVING ON Collaboration~ www.MovingOnMovie.com

campaign.story:
Now in it's third online season, The Peregrine Dame with host Rachel Parsons explores what it's like to travel completely alone. No camera crew, no friends. TPD is a unique blend of Survivorman and Samantha Brown. A true documentary travel series, TPD is a short format show (each episode is 4-6 minutes in length) that delivers a lot for such a small package.
TPD is currently seeking funding to complete editing on the third season and market the show heavily through out online portals to expand the audience and expose the show to new people who love travel and a little learning all wrapped up into one. We intend to use about half of our fund raising goal to finish editing the last 10 episodes and the other half to purchase relevant advertising through Google Adwords, on Youtube and Facebook and other targeted travel and entertainment sites to spread the word. We need to build up our audience because we are being looked at by larger web portals that are interested in the series, but we need to deliver the eyeballs!
To view the first two seasons, and the beginning of the third season, please visit www.theperegrinedame.com or look us up on Facebook, iTunes and Youtube.

updates.update_userinfo: TPD accepted into ITVFest in L.A. in August
updates.update_content:
Hi Everyone,
 Just a quick note to let you know the good news. TPD has been accepted into the International Television Festival here in LA in August! Details can be found through www.itvfest.org.
Also, I am nearly done editing the last episode of TPD as it stands now and I will be getting those DVD's to you as soon as I can. Promise! Thanks for your patience and support. You can also see some older TPD episodes now on Window Media Guide, which has picked up the series. We love their viewers. All 14 million of them a month!

updates.update_userinfo: Thank you credits and Windows Media Guide
updates.update_content:
Hello All,
I just want to give a quick update and assure you that I have not forgotten rewards, etc., The exciting news is that we are talking to various distribution outlets and that means lots of work. The not so good news is that the work means I am polishing all 20 episodes that previously existed before season three and that means I have to put the rest of S3 cutting on hold for a couple of weeks. So bear with me, because I'm sure that all of you have been chomping at the bit to get your credits and the DVDs. Waiting with baited breath, I know.

I promise that each of you will get a personal (if emailed) thank you from me at some point this month! But first, news; TPD is in the stage that's exciting but pencil-pushing intensive. I'm signing paper work that will at least preliminarily let outside platforms view the series for licensing consideration. To me that's very exciting. As soon as I have more definite info and hopefully offers, I'll update you! And also I'm trying to get the episodes out as fast as possible, although I'm having to re-cut things for these outside companies to view; as soon as the complete London and Bruges episodes are ready, I will get the DVDs out to everyone who requested them.

And most of all, I thanks you. All of you. We made our goal plus some extra, and now we have a good amount to advertise the series with. Most of the money will buy Goodle Adwords ads and some will be used for Facebook ads, and a bit will be used to put together the TPD submission for ITVFest's yearly Internet and TV festival and competition.
I really do feel this is the year that the series really shines, and now you're all a part of that.
Thank you so much, and for those of you that wanted them, you will be getting screen credits starting with episode 307, coming out in another week or so, and the complete series DVDs will be sent once the complete third season is cut. We have more fun from South Africa coming and then lots of London and Bruges. I hope you enjoy and again; thank you.
Rachel

updates.update_userinfo: My Mudda thanks you and my Fadda thanks you...
updates.update_content:
Hi Everyone,
I believe I have found someone who wants to provide the rest of the pledge amount, so I want to say a huge thank you to all of you who have pledged; it's actually made the project doable!
Will be updating again soon.
Not that any of you need to, but the project has to raise a minimum of $2500, but there's no maximum, so if you know of anyone who wants to pitch in $10 bucks or however much, we're allowed to raise as much as we can before noon tomorrow, Pacific time.
Again thank you so much and some of you will be getting DVD's and some will be getting credit on TPD, so stay tuned.
-Rachel

updates.update_userinfo: I think it's going to happen.
updates.update_content:
I just want to take a moment and say thank you to all of you for pledging. I wish I could extend the deadline, but you can't do that once you've set it here. There are 48 hours left, and I'm trying to rally a few more troops, but what you've done so far means a lot. Thank you to all of you and although I won't get any of your funding come Saturday if I don't hit the full pledge amount, I will remember that each of you was willing to support the show and it warms my oft-times cold heart. :)
-Rachel

Hi Everyone,
First of all thanks so much for everything you've pledged. As you can see we have 10 days to go and a lot more funds to raise. If you know of anyone who might be even slightly interested in helping the series, please send them the link and a note.
As to progress, we've been approached in recent weeks by a couple of new media distribution companies who are interested in licensing the series, which is amazing; so deals should be in the works this year. We also sent a proposal for sponsorship to a major airline this week and are waiting to hear back. So things are cooking! But we still need to be able to advertise and market TPD in the meantime, so again, if you have anyone - a rich old uncle, say - or a friend who might want to blow $5, please spread the word.
Thank you!
Rachel

Hi Everyone,
I just wanted to take a minute to say thank you all so much for being the first group to back TPD. It means a lot, and although I know each of you personally, I still love your money too. Although, it's really your rich friends' money I want.
Kidding aside, really, sincerely, thank you. I'll let you all know how it goes February 26th!
Love,
Rachel

campaign.story:
The Goal
We would like to continue development on JSONloops, our open-source real-time multiuser audio sequencer that works cross-browser. We are software hackers and music producers who grew up learning on simple tools like Fruityloops. We aren't aiming to build the world's most complex audio sequencer, we wish to create a simple tool that the next generation of software developers and musicians can learn from. Think Fruityloops, but in a web-page and multiple users can edit the same song at once.
This sounds like a very complex technical goal to achieve, but we have already completed a working prototype which won Best Collaborative Hack at NYC Music Hack Day 2011. JSONloops has been mentioned on TechCrunch, The New York Observer, and CreateDigitalMusic.com. We've gotten a tremendous amount of positive feedback and even more requests to release JSONloops as a full fledged open-source project.
Older video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MSZLLgel6Gs
Open JSON format
JSONloops songs are composed entirely in JSON. JSON is a widely used plaintext format for storing and exchanging data on the web. It is the standard which services like Google, Twitter, Flickr, and Facebook utilize for sharing and receiving data. JSON is supported by every modern programming language to date.
A JSONloops server emits and can receive a standard JSON message on every step of the sequencer. This means that a developer could easily write software in any language to extend JSONloops. It also means that songs can be remixed and edited using existing tools, or even just a plain text editor!
The Community
While developing a functional piece of software is critical, it's also very important to us that we build a vibrant open community around the project. We know from experience, that community is one the pillars of success in any open-source software project.
Why are we asking for money?
We need funding for software development costs. JSONloops is open-source, but it will require hundreds, if not thousands of hours of software development to reach a stable version (v.1.0.0 in semantic versioning ). Aside from the core team of developers, we plan to hire a series of "open-source" interns to work on the project. This small amount of funding will allow us to accelerate the pace of development for the project, as well as give a great incentive to inspire developers to join the project. We have the experience necessary in leading open-source projects, and the network of developers ready to make this possible.
The Team
Marak Squires, Elijah Insua , hij1nx Click on any team member's name or picture to see their Github open-source profile. Github is a place where open-source developers share and develop source code. We love Github!
The Sponsor
The company I work for has been very gracious in offering free hosting for the JSONloops project. This will allow us to not have to worry about paying for hosting costs! Thank you Nodejitsu, the best node.js hosting provider ever!
When do you expect this to be complete?
If we can successfully raise enough money, we plan to release version 1.0.0 in Fall of 2011. We expect to start the online beta for all donors sometime in the next three months.

campaign.story:
Do you have what it takes to be an Evil Genius? Can you keep the robot factory working despite the wily meddling of Tesla Ranger spies? Find out in this new game for the iPod, iPad, and other mobile devices.
Machination puts the player in the role of a would-be Evil Genius doing the fiendish bidding of the nefarious organization FAUST!
In the latest bid to rule the world, FAUST's devious scientists have developed a series of malevolent machines designed for the sole purpose of causing havoc. FAUST's implacable foes, the Tesla Rangers, have dispatched spies to infiltrate the organization's robot factories and disrupt production.
Needless to say, FAUST has other ideas. You have been instructed to keep the factory working and catch those spies! At last, a chance to rise above the ranks of other minions and prove your worth as an Evil Genius!
In MACHINATION, you must collect the necessary robot parts from the factory's conveyors and place them in order onto the robot blueprint. Building the correct number of robots completes a level and moves you deeper into the factory, where more complex robot orders are required, and the conveyors move ever faster! Catching the Tesla spies helps the factory run smoother, and collecting cogs allows you to acquire new devices to aid you in your task.
Working in the Unity engine provides us with great flexibility from project to project, and allows us to master a toolset that can be deployed on a number of platforms. Part of our funding requirement is to acquire the appropriate licenses for this versatile software. In addition, we are currently working with borrowed hardware. With your help, we’ll be able to return this gear to its rightful owners and use our own. I’m sure these friends will be as grateful to you for your generosity as we are.
In addition, we want to make sure the game is as professional as possible. The video shows our working prototype which is fully functional and has almost all the features we need to launch the game. We do need to spend time replacing the art with production quality art, and adding the level of polish needed to make a game really stand out. To this end, we will be contracting an audio expert to create our sounds and music for us (a key aspect we're missing right now). He’s been incredibly generous with his time so far, but he’s a professional and needs to be paid for his work. Your funding will help us to provide the most polished package we can.
Once the game is complete our work really begins. Making headway in the app store is a full-time job, and the only way to make a game a success is to work hard promoting it. Any marketing effort at all takes time and money, and we expect to have to work very hard indeed to rise above the general noise in the store. We are fortunate enough to have a number of friends and former colleagues who have already enjoyed tremendous success in the app store and will be able to benefit greatly from their help and experience. Part of the funding you provide will help us to get those initial first week sales necessary to get a game ranked and listed. Getting the game in front of players is crucial and we need your help to make it happen.
Obviously we think Machination is a great game or we wouldn’t be asking for your help in releasing it. It is by no means our only game, however. In fact we’re bursting with great ideas that we think would make awesome apps and we really want to develop that next game, and the one after that.
But before we can start thinking about our next project, we need to launch Machination, and for that we need your help. If you can, please help us reach our goal by making a pledge. You may notice that none of the rewards offered includes a copy of the game itself. This was a conscious decision, as every sale of the game in the app store will help us in the rankings and gaining attention that way is vital for our first game. To make this omission more palatable, you'll also notice that we've deducted a dollar from each of the nice round numbers we initially calculated. We hope you'll spend that dollar wisely and support us in the app store with a purchase once Machination is available.
Signal Flare is the brainchild of two game developers who want to continue making great games with their good friends and colleagues. Former studios for which we have worked have fallen victim to the whims of investors and the vicissitudes of a turbulent economy, and this is an opportunity to control our own fate and hopefully build our own studio, whose sole focus is to build entertaining products. See our profile for more information.
Thanks for taking the time to read about this project, we really hope you’ll help us to realize our grand ambition, or at the very least, make that first step along the path.

updates.update_content:
This is incredibly hard to write. Acknowledging my failures and the mistakes I made is a bitter pill. I should have done it a long time ago, but I’m ashamed to say that I hid from it for way too long.
This campaign was intended to be the starting point for a small studio owned by a friend of mine to make mobile games. The economy was doing badly and two games studios we had been part of closed unexpectedly, one owing us most of a year’s salary.

Unsurprisingly, there were a good number of address changes that came in after the last update. We have updated the records accordingly and the first batch of mailings have been sent. The rest will be mailed by the weekend, which will take care of the bulk of the printed material. The only thing that remains is to release the game.

We have received the printed postcards featuring Cheyenne's awesome artwork, and they look fantastic.
It's been a while since we had some images for you, so here are a couple of shots of our shiny robots in all their glory.

Just a short update this week. We had been hoping to post an image of the finished postcards this weekend, but they didn't come back to us in time. We are told they'll be delivered this week, so I'll post an update when they arrive. Then we'll have them packed up and shipped out over the weekend!

The work on In-App purchasing continues, along with the design-side work of balancing the number of cogs (the in-game currency) received for various game actions against the number that can be acquired by a purchase.

We have conquered the text issues we were experiencing on Android and have good stable builds on our test devices. We are currently looking at the changes we need to make to support a wide range of other devices.

The last couple of weeks have been spent making various adjustments to the game for Android. We're continuing to refine the UI and will have screenshots of the menus and options by the end of this week.

campaign.story:
Beyond 60
We've reached our initial fundraising goal, but we're still going strong. More money helps us found the project stronger, reach goals faster and explore more technologies of freedom. We're proud of the Freedom Box Foundation's public roots, and we want to be able to demonstrate support and interest from as many people as possible. So thank you to everyone who has pledged so far and please, keep pledging and keep giving.
$60K was a floor, not a ceiling. It is the minimum we need to start making this a real project, but it is not enough to fully fund the project. The more money we raise from the public, the more money we can raise from industry and grants. Even $1 donations help us prove the viability of our efforts.
We are right now trying to get some public attention focused on how quickly we hit $60K. So keep telling your friends about the project and the this site. We'd like to surge over the top and finish strong.
Congratulations to us all for the collective effort we've made so far. And thanks again, for all your ideas, your time, your energy and your donations!
Welcome web readers!
If you're coming from the any of the recent stories about Eben Moglen and the creation of the FreedomBox Foundation (NY Times, WSJ, BoingBoing, Slashdot, reddit, ZDNet, The New York Observer, New Europe, techPresident, etc) please check out the FreedomBox Foundation's website and read here for more information about the project.
What is Freedom Box?
Freedom Box is the name we give to a free software system built to keep your communications free and private whether chatting with friends or protesting in the street.
Freedom Box software is particularly tailored to run in "plug servers," which are compact computers that are no larger than the power adapters for electronic appliances.
Located in people's homes or offices such inexpensive servers can provide privacy in normal life, and safe communications for people seeking to preserve their freedom in oppressive regimes.
Why Freedom Box?
Because social networking and digital communications technologies are now critical to people fighting to make freedom in their societies or simply trying to preserve their privacy where the Web and other parts of the Net are intensively surveilled by profit-seekers and government agencies. Yet, instead of technology supporting these new modes of communications, smartphones, mobile tablets, and other common forms of consumer electronics are being built as "platforms" to control their users and monitor their activity.
Freedom Box exists to provide people with privacy-respecting technology alternatives that enable normal communication in normal times, and that offer ways to collaborate safely and securely with others in building social networks of protest, demonstration, and mobilization for political change in the not-so-normal times.
Imagine if your next wireless router, or settop box, or other small computing device came with extra features. It knew how to securely contact your friends and business associates, it stored your personal data, securely backing it up and generally maintaining your presence in the various networks you have come to rely on for communicating with people in society.
Such a box would not only make your participation in network communication easier in your daily life, increasing your privacy and the security of computers in your life, it would have many unique advantages during times of crisis.
Such a box could help in disasters by creating a mesh network with your neighbors to replace the centralized internet connections that go out with the lights or are cut by hostile governments. Such a box would make it harder for governments and invasive corporate interests to reach your data and casually profile you for their own uses. Such a box would also let you lend aid to friends in need by sharing your unfettered internet access with those trapped behind government firewalls that prevent them from learning about the world or speaking plainly to it.
Such boxes exist in the form of plug computers and mesh routers, tiny, inexpensive machines that can take the place of other electronics in your life, that draw so little power (often as little as 5W) that they can be run off of batteries or solar panels. We even have free software, software meant to empower and support individuals, to do all of the things mentioned above.
What we need is the glue to hold all of that together, the architecture of which pieces stack together in which way to turn a collection of possibilities into an appliance so easy to use that you forget you even have one, at least until that moment when you really need it. The FreedomBox Foundation was built to put this all together. It was started by community leaders with long track records and lives as a community project. But the past few months have shown us all that there are millions of people around the world who need such a device now and we need to pick up the pace and get them made so that next time, our friends have some help. That is why we are asking for your help.
In Need of Community Angels
There are many people out there, in many different communities, who feel the same way we do about profiling, internet kill switches, and the need to give people greater independence in their network communications, but turning all that interest and the offers of help into a real software suite is going to take coordination, organization, and bringing people together in focused groups to get this system built. That is why the FreedomBox Foundation was created, but it requires real work and a real demonstration of community size and support to keep everything moving. If we can meet our funding goal now, we can start doing that work full time, build road maps for the core components, and put together a series of conferences/hack days to pull the community together.
The Freedom Box is a community based endeavor from the ground up. That includes everything from architecture and engineering through to administration and funding. It's the reason why we're seeking the first round of investment from our own community. We want it to be clear that this project begins and remains in the hands of the people who give it life at every stage and in every part of the project.
Almost all the software we need to make this work is already out there in the free software world, but if we are going to pull it all together, first we need to get up to speed. Please join us and help keep the momentum going from 0 to 60!
When will we get the software?
The release timeline for this software depends a good deal on how much support we can gather this month, which is why we are reaching out now. If we can reach our goal, we hope to release a first version of the software six months later. This is our best working etimate but we will know a lot more in the next 30 days and will continue to update everyone here and on the Foundation's website. If you are pledging enough for any of the software rewards ($50 and up), know that we hope to have everything shipped out within in week of the 0.1 release, if not on the release day itself, and please keep your eye here and on the Foundation site for updates.

updates.update_content:
Sales Have Launched
The big day is finally here: sales of the first commercially available FreedomBox have launched! The Pioneer Edition FreedomBox Home Server Kits can be purchased here: https://www.olimex.com/Products/OLinuXino/Home-Server/Pioneer-FreedomBox-HSK/
The product is being sold by Olimex, a company which specializes in Open Source Hardware. The product includes everything you need to host your own home server: pocket-sized server hardware, an SD card with the FreedomBox system pre-installed, and a backup battery which can power the hardware for 4-5 hours in case of outages. It sells for €82 and ships globally.

Hello, backers! It's been a while, but we have some exciting news for you: In partnership with the FreedomBox Foundation, Olimex will soon be selling Pioneer FreedomBox Home Servers for €82! The FreedomBox home servers will come with the LIME2 single-board computer, our software pre-installed, a backup battery in case of power outage, and everything else you need to get started. The Pioneer edition FreedomBox Home Server will be the first commercially available version of FreedomBox. Sales have not launched yet, but they will launch soon.
 Offer for Kickstarter backers:

For those of you who have not heard through mailing list or in the project's IRC channel (#freedombox on http://www.oftc.net/), FreedomBox has reached the 0.2 release. This second release is still intended for developers but represents a significant maturation of the components we have discussed here in the past and a big step forward for the project as a whole.
0.2 features

I am pleased to announce our first FreedomBox software release. The FreedomBox 0.1 image is available here (.torrent) (sha512sum: 867f5bf462102daef82a34165017b9e67ed8e09116fe46edd67730541bbfb731083850ab5e28ee40bdbc5054cb64e4d0e46a201797f27e0b8f0d2881ef083b40).
This 0.1 version is primarily a developer release, which means that it focuses on architecture and infrastructure rather than finish work. The exception to this is privoxy-freedombox, the web proxy discussed in previous updates, which people can begin using right now to make their web browsing more secure and private and which will very soon be available on non-FreedomBox systems. More information on that tool at the end of this post.

After two weeks of editing and polishing it looks like our first kickstarter software release will not ship out with the rest of the rewards on the 31st. At the moment we are looking to release during the week of August 6th, which means software will hit the web just as most of you receive your tee-shirts. We will be announcing the release here as soon as it goes live and then immediately begin imaging the microSD cards and printing the commemorative CD's for shipment. That should take a week to complete so then everything in that final shipment will go out around the middle of August.

The last two weeks have been very busy ones for the FreedomBox development community. The two hackfests I mentioned in the previous email, at the annual Debian conference (DebCon) in Nicaragua and at before the Hackers on Planet Earth (HOPE) conference in New York, were well attended and very productive. I will cover the highlights here and anyone who is interested in more details, in particular about the activities at HOPE, should take a look at the most recent news at the freedomboxfoundation.org website. 
The biggest highlight is that we will have an initial developer release at the end of the month. We are working very hard over the weekend to figure out if we will have that internally with enough time to print the CD and microSD cards we will be shipping as part of the kickstarter rewards. Expect final word on that this coming Tuesday.

Hi again everyone. It is past time for an update on a number of fronts and I am glad to say that we have some news to share.
Rewards
I want to start by saying that we have not forgotten any of our commitments to the community and to you for the pledges that got the foundation off the ground.

updates.update_userinfo: It's the most merchandized time of the year
updates.update_content: Apparently everyone with a screen printer and access to the US postal system has been booked solid making end of year merchandise since before Thanksgiving. That means our printing needs are going to get pushed to the middle of January, unless someone in the kickstarter knows a quality tee shirt / bag printer. If you know who we should work with, please drop me a message. Either way the microSD card readers and stickers are in process and everything is on track for sending out in the next 4-6 weeks.

updates.update_userinfo: The new face of the FreedomBox
updates.update_content:
I am pleased to announce at long last the new FreedomBox logo! 
This new piece of design comes thanks to the work of our new community working group for visual identity and with special thanks to Robert Martinez.
The new logo, combined with the alpha developers release of our build image at https://www.freedomboxfoundation.org/code/ finally make it possible to provide everyone here with a more tangible expression of our heartfelt thanks for your support.

A lot of people have been asking for an update, which is a good indication that we need to update folks more often.
Bdale Garbee will be at DebConf11.  He and Clint Adams will be running a hackfest.  If you are going to be there (a lot of FreedomBoxers are also Debian devs), please track him down and ask him any question you have about the box. His answers will be thoughtful and perhaps surprising.

campaign.story:
The Last Cosmonaut is the story of the last secretly launched Soviet space pilot in 1958.
His existence has never been acknowledged by the Russian government. Every record of his launch was destroyed. He was last detected by the Torre Bert observatory in February, 1961.
It is believed he now stands as the first and only person to ever leave the solar system.
TLC will be a five minute short film depicting the Cosmonaut's last moments in orbit. It will be shot in 35mm anamorphic on Russian lenses and cameras. The costumes and props are all accurate replicas.
I hope to raise the remaining half of budget in order to pay for costume rentals, set construction, food, equipment, and transportation. I am putting up the first 50% from personal savings, as I wholly believe in the project and in telling this story. This film is the last project of my college career, and is as ambitious as anything I've attempted.

updates.update_content:
That you for sticking with us, and I'm sorry if you have not received the updates either by the e-mail list or under the comments section.
I am ecstatic to announce tat by the end of the weekend, the film will be completely finished! That includes the visual effects that have taken us so long to nail down due to unforseen complications.
I will release an more thorough email shortly, and copy it here, but I wanted to promptly reply to those who have been questioning the film's status recently.

Congratulations, everyone!
We've reached 100 backers, and have nearly doubled our initial goal. It couldn't have happened without every single one of you, and I am incredibly grateful for it.
As promised, everyone will now receive an advance storyboard book, as well as a script, once the donation period ends in 4 days. That's when there will be a drawing for the 3 hard copies, so keep an eye out!

Hey, everyone!
With just 6 days to go and 7 backers away from reaching 100, I wanted to post a little tease for you.
Our incredible composer Mark Krench has begun creating pre-cues for the film, and composed this beautiful theme for our character, Alinka. Here's a mix for everyone to download and enjoy!

Hey, Everybody!
Let me extend my thanks again to everyone who's contributed to the project!
And now, let me pose you one last challenge:
We currently have amazing storyboards all done by fantastic Chicago Artist Mary Cotton.

First, to state the obvious; WE DID IT!
Thank you to everyone who helped in making this project become a reality. There's no way we could have done it alone, and I'm so glad everyone has chosen to become a part of the film. This is a very special project for me, and I look forward to making it up to everyone's expectations.
Secondly; I wanted to post another promo for everyone to see and share with everyone else. Send it around and let everyone know that you're a part of this great project.

campaign.story:
If you haven’t heard, the Space Shuttle program will come to an end after 30 years of service when the space shuttle Atlantis returns from the program’s final mission later this year. With over 1 million parts the orbiter is the most complex device built to date and has inspired people all over the world.
Our focus is telling the story of the amazing Space Shuttle program, including behind the scenes activities and the people, from plumbers to astronauts, who were involved in making it happen. We are capturing this story not only with photography and cinematography, but also, infrared, surround sound, 360 VR and 3D motion and stills. We are creating not only a documentary but an immersive experience. You can check out samples of our work at http://thelastshuttle.com/imagery.aspx
Once the project is completed, its content will be used in museums including the San Diego Air and Space Museum (http://www.sandiegoairandspace.org/ ) to educate future generations. Historians, educators, aerospace enthusiasts and people all over the world will be able to experience the excitement and adventure of the Space Shuttle program. You can learn more about our project at www.thelastshuttle.com or join us on FaceBook - http://tinyurl.com/46eqkzx
Your funding and support will go towards production expenses such as transportation, lodging, food, and equipment. With shuttle preparations in several states our expenses add up quickly and ideally extra funding would allow us to have team members onsite full time at various locations to capture history in the making.
Thanks for your support, The Last Shuttle Team

updates.update_content: ...so the team is back in Cocoa Beach getting ready for Mondays launch. We have 6 people on location now with another two arriving tomorrow. Preparation of the remote setups is going smoothly but of course I can't help but be concerned. We will see! The big upside is everyone has time to get a good nights sleep. Weather looks good for the launch though it was raining today. Photo is of Cathy's room with the cameras placed inside of camera housings.

The shuttle launch has been postponed until at least May 8th. The team is taking down gear and most are heading back to their homes Monday with Cathy staying to wrap up some details on Tuesday. We will let you know as soon as NASA announces a firm launch date. Hopefully we will have time to pull all of the team together for it. Photo is of Paul Griffith, Jeffery Ross, and Bob Fisher covering up a remote camera on Saturday.
You can follow todays launch of STS-134 at http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/shuttle/launch/launch_blog.html

Daily Report.
 Thelastshuttle.com team fanned out today en force at Kennedy Space Center. 6am, Bob, Jeff, Steve and Brendan were in the pad perimeter to place our complex camera rigs to full effect for the launch of Endeavour. Each liftoff brings us a wealth of imagery and experience. 
The rest of the team - Cathy, Jook, Rhonda, Paul and John - laid the groundwork for the rest of our 15-hour day... arranging interviews, data wrangling, integrating new equipment, generating our social networking content, schedule juggling and more! It was a very busy day, with anticipation high for the arrival of President Obama tomorrow. Brendan conducted an astronaut interview, with more to film tomorrow - along with a planned one on one with veteran NBC space correspondent Jay Barbree. More camera setups were placed near the pad, just before a major lightning storm hit and cleared the press center of those waiting to head to the pad for RSS rollback, a milestone in the count. The delay gave is time to grab a late dinner in Cocoa Beach - we're waiting for word that work can resume safely at the pad. Steve got some spectacular shots of lightning to the east of the VAB!

Hi all
Tomorrow is the launch of space shuttle Endeavour STS-134, its final flight before it is retired by NASA. The Last Shuttle Project's team has been crazed getting equipment ready and placing the cameras.
Right now they are on a hold. It seems that NASA does not have enough of the required sand bags to weigh down the tripod legs. John Cathy and Jeffrey had to run to hardware store to buy some. Wonder if this would put a mission hold on the launch :-)  Be sure to check out our facebook page we have are posting our progress.

In case you haven't heard...
http://www.spaceflightnow.com/shuttle/sts134/110420obama/
The first of our team, Bob, will arrive in Florida on Sunday. The remaining 8 will arrive steadily with all on site by Wednesday night. Thursday beginning at 6a is remote camera set-up day. We have 9 camera set-ups planned around the Pad and we're looking forward to some awesome capture.

Hello everyone...
The launch of space shuttle Endeavour has been rescheduled for April 29. The push back from April 19th had us all spinning but we're back on track. Team members are busy preparing for their arrivals beginning April 25.
Your support of our project was significant in making this launch happen for us. The names of our Kickstarter backers have been submitted for publication at our website www.thelastshuttle.com. Some of you still haven't responded to the survey. Please send your name as you would like to be listed and your address so that your reward can be forwarded. We appreciate your support and want to see you recognized.

updates.update_userinfo: The President and family to attend the shuttle launch
updates.update_content:
In case you haven't heard.....
   WASHINGTON -- After 30 years of spaceflight, more than 130 missions, and numerous science and technology firsts, NASA's space shuttle fleet will retire and be on display at institutions across the country to inspire the next generation of explorers and engineers.  NASA Administrator Charles Bolden on Tuesday announced the facilities where four shuttle orbiters will be displayed permanently at the conclusion of the Space Shuttle Program. Shuttle Enterprise, the first orbiter built, will move from the Smithsonian's National Air and Space Museum Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Center in Virginia to the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum in New York. The Udvar-Hazy Center will become the new home for shuttle Discovery, which retired after completing its 39th mission in March. Shuttle Endeavour, which is preparing for its final flight at the end of the month, will go to the California Science Center in Los Angeles. Atlantis, which will fly the last planned shuttle mission in June, will be displayed at the Kennedy Space Center Visitor Complex in Florida.  "We want to thank all of the locations that expressed an interest in one of these national treasures," Bolden said. "This was a very difficult decision, but one that was made with the American public in mind. In the end, these choices provide the greatest number of people with the best opportunity to share in the history and accomplishments of NASA's remarkable Space Shuttle Program. These facilities we've chosen have a noteworthy legacy of preserving space artifacts and providing outstanding access to U.S. and international visitors."  NASA also announced that hundreds of shuttle artifacts have been allocated to museums and education institutions.  - Various shuttle simulators for the Adler Planetarium in Chicago, the Evergreen Aviation & Space Museum of McMinnville, Ore., and Texas A&M's Aerospace Engineering Department  - Full fuselage trainer for the Museum of Flight in Seattle  - Nose cap assembly and crew compartment trainer for the National Museum of the U.S. Air Force at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio  - Flight deck pilot and commander seats for NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston

campaign.story:
Reality blurs in a short SCIFI/Drama about as a recluse ending 5 years of self-confinement to fight his addiction to technology.
What we’re doing: Do you remember the feeling when you walk out of a great film and can’t stop thinking about it? When you were truly touched by the story? When you were blown away and your awareness was raised to a new level? This is what we want to give people. We want to tell a world class story and we want you to be a part of that. We have spent our lives in the pursuit of making great films, and now we want to take it a step further, but we need your help to do it! With your help, we will produce a short movie that will rival Hollywood films in production value, flair, emotional impact and message.
Using Kickstarter, we will raise the 10,000 dollars we need to make this film together, and if we can’t, it all gets refunded. It’s all or nothing.
So we’re seeking 200 supporters to give $50 each, but we appreciate any help you can offer, so it's something anyone can be a part of. If you can help with more, that’s great. For this support there are plenty of incentives, check out the list to the right.
Why are we're doing it?: Has anyone ever told you “No, you can’t do that, it will never happen” “That’s impossible”. “Just give up”, “Live in the real world”. “You can’t be a singer, you can’t be a pirate, and you can’t be an astronaut and build your own space ship.”
Well, we say, we’re all kids and dreamers, maybe the little girl or boy is buried, but that they can never take away from us.
My name’s Scott Mannion. I love movies, I've always loved movies, and hopefully, if you’re reading this, you love movies too. We’re just normal people like you, normal people with big dreams; dreams people told us weren't possible. We love telling and sharing stories and we want to share this passion with as many people as we can.
We joined Kickstarter to see this film realised because we believe in the story. What you just saw was the trailer for our film, all we could do with the money we had. To finish the film, we need help from the dreamers out there, the movie lovers out there, to create something that is truly ours. Will you join us?
What are we going to do with the film once it's made?: We will enter ‘Anima’ into over 100 International Film Festivals where we hope it will collect numerous awards. We are also confident that it will reach the short list for Oscar nomination for Best Short Film, which is our goal. To be in the running for the Oscar short list we need to win 1 of 100 Academy accredited film festivals. (E.g Sydney Film Festival, Toronto Film Festival, Sundance Film Festival.) Any further than that is just part of the adventure.
What is the money spent on?: All of the money raised will be spent on the film’s production. We’ve assembled a top tier industry crew yet no-one will be taking a fee, just expenses. The lead actor will be a household name who you will recognise. This is the key to the success of the film. Every penny will be up there on screen for you and everyone else to see. Anima will be shot on 35mm film, sound-mixed in Dolby and presented digitally at Screen Australia Studios within 6 months of today.
If I donate, when can I redeem the incentive?: All incentives, big and small, will only happen if our goal is met. If we do meet our goal, immediately after we finish the film we will begin to ship and send out the DVD's, and tickets to the private premiere will be sent in the mail.
How can I contact you?: Glad you asked! You can contact us at: info@singularityfilms.net, also, check out the website at: www.animafilm.com.au which is updated regularly with blogs about film and announcements to keep you involved in the adventure. Tell your friends!
My sincere thanks for your help and support.
Your fellow dreamer! - Scott Mannion

If you are a business or an individual; any way you can help us is appreciated, whether it be recommending us to a contact or just telling a friend about the film over a coffee.

As we draw closer to the end of our post production period, I thought it would be a good time to let everyone know that the project is coming along much better then I'd hoped for. We are now beginning our CGI effects, composition and sound design; I can see the light at the end of the tunnel, and upon reflecting, I never imagined the project would turn out this well. I never imagined the avenues I would choose or the epic amount of work I would put in when I began this project. I pleased, but not surprised.
Because when one is bold, great things can happen.

campaign.story:
My dad says he’s lived two lives, but I think it's more. He has sailed to Iran as a merchant seaman, driven a tank over exploding kimchee vats in Korea, and survived two prisoner-of-war camps in Japan during WWII. You wouldn't know by looking at him - I only found out after I saw a curious scar on his back and I started asking questions. And then I asked more questions.
Recently, my dad showed me a secret diary he kept while he was a prisoner of war in Japan during WWII. I was shocked. Also excited, and touched. Why show me? Why now? Why were there some pages missing? It was like a window into his nineteen-year-old mind, into his soul. Are we really that similar? No. I try, I try very hard – to emulate his kindness, generosity and tenacity. Life to him is pretty black and white. Things just are. This resoluteness, this assuredness – I don’t have that at all. Life to me is all shades of grey, of maybes and possibilities.
I read the old, carefully penned pages, and start to daydream and ask questions. It starts to make sense, why every day as a free man is a holiday. What ceases to amaze me is that as much as he wants to tell me stories from his past, he is still very much part of the present.
He won’t be around forever, which is why this unique look into a family – an American family with international ties – is timely and important. Please help me finish making this film, EVERY DAY IS A HOLIDAY.
To watch the special Kickstarter trailer, click on the video above and you'll see my dad embarrass me in the first 20 seconds.
WHY PLEDGE? EVERY DAY IS A HOLIDAY has been green-lit by the Independent Television Service (ITVS)!
We need your help to bring EVERY DAY IS A HOLIDAY to public television! The Independent Television Service (ITVS) has green-lit our film and will provide $79,000 in matching funds towards the completion of the film once we contribute $34,496. We hope to raise as much of these funds as possible on Kickstarter. So far, we've received over $10,000 in pledges. Thank you! The funds we receive will be used for post-production. But there's still more to go!
Help us meet the challenge! And score tickets to the premiere, an exclusive interview from the director, your name in the credits, and more!
Make pledges of ANY AMOUNT on KICKSTARTER. EVERY dollar you pledge will go DIRECTLY to post-production and help bring the film to public television. Sample costs include:
$1000 one day of sound design
$2500 basic map animation
$7500 editing sessions
$10000 archival licensing
The last day to pledge is February 28! Please help us meet our FUNDRAISING GOAL to get our matching funds.
FAQ Where can I learn more about the project? Please visit the official website: http://www.everydayisaholiday.org. You will find more information about the film, the cast, and relevant posts about documentaries, filmmaking and WWII. You’ll get an inside peek into the director’s slightly quirky brain.
How else can I help? You can also help by telling others! Become a fan of our Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Every-Day-Is-a-Holiday-Documentary-Film/170949786281906
Why not set your goal as $34,496? $8,000 was our initial Kickstarter goal to continue with post-production, since Kickstarter is an all or nothing fundraising platform. We are also applying for grants from foundations. It's quite a process, so we very much appreciate your support!
Don't want to pledge online? Email us at info*at*everydayisaholiday*dot*org and we'll tell you how to do it offline.
Thank you for your support!
